## Disclaimer
This shows a few scratch ideas on how to come up with a bash script to do a local branching of a git-project. The idea is that the different branches should be located in different subdirectory under a root-project directory.


## Introduction and Background


## Scratch Ideas Based On History Excerpt

```{bash, eval=FALSE}
### define a few variables that describe the process
  591  BRANCH=gh-pages
  593  PROJECT=NewEbvGoat
  594  PROJROOT=${PROJECT}_ROOT
### # create the new directories for the branches below the given root  
  595  mkdir -p $PROJROOT/master $PROJROOT/$BRANCH
### # copy the existing project into the branch subdirectories  
  596  cp -R $PROJECT $PROJROOT/master
       cp -R $PROJECT $PROJROOT/$BRANCH
### # cd to the branch subdir and change to the git-branch
cd $PROJROOT/$BRANCH/$PROJECT
  637  git branch $BRANCH
  640  git checkout $BRANCH
### # delete old master branch  
  644  git branch -d master
### # push  
git add .
git commit -m "First commit to branch"
git push origin $BRANCH
```
